objects.name: Unhinged Writing on Screens
objects.excerpt: NO NO NO I don’t want to linger in front of screens or projectors. Please god no. I know I already do, but.

objects.name: Weeknotes
objects.excerpt: Every week for the second semester of my junior year at Cooper I wrote a long-winded report on what I was doing, thinking about, and working on.

objects.name: If We Are Digital
objects.excerpt: In just seven days I helped launch this website hosting a series of conversations between Jen Lindblad and people working to engage online art audiences.

objects.name: Pool
objects.excerpt: Eight months after contributing a piece of writing to Pool, a publication about internet art, and one passive-agressive message later I ended up working with Founder and Lead Editor Louis Doulas to develop the site's second iteration. While staying true to Louis's intensely stark mockups, we arrived at a better reading experience and managed to make a ton of subtle, under-the-hood improvements to the site's functionality. The site's homepage bares a list of everything ever published by Pool, with visited links shown in gray. This allows readers to leave and return to the site and remember what is left to be explored.

objects.name: Two Apologies President Bharucha Must Make
objects.excerpt: An open letter to the president of Cooper Union.

objects.name: Sweaty Tube
objects.excerpt: Watch YouTube videos on a sweater. Made with Alex Gibson and Aaron Graham.

objects.name: You Can't Fuck the System If You've Never Met One
objects.excerpt: “Part of the reason systems are hard to see is because they're an abstraction. They don't really exist until you articulate them. And any two things don't make a system, even where there are strong correlations. Towns with more trees have lower divorce rates, for example, but you'd be hard-pressed to go anywhere with that. However, if you can manage to divine the secret connections and interdependencies between things, it's like putting on glasses for the first time.”

objects.name: Programmed Visions Book Review
objects.excerpt: “As more and more people find themselves able to create things out of code, it feels critical to understand software on both a practical and fundamental level.”

objects.name: CooperUnion.biz
objects.excerpt: The website of Cooper Union from an alternate universe where the grubby administration gets their way. Alex Gibson and Aaron Graham.

objects.name: Between the Spreadsheets
objects.excerpt: Fighting a corrupt bureacracy with...seduction.

objects.name: User-Generated Content
objects.excerpt: The way things are now is more like a pile up of metaphors and recycled code than laws of interaction which are set in stone. Designing computer systems is a strangely direct way of altering how people experience the world and relate to each other. Perhaps in the coming years artists will be able to create new platforms with the conceptual backbone that is lacking in today’s popular offerings.

objects.name: Until I get better at coding, there will be no...
objects.excerpt: One day I will read something and feel the hypothetical ecstasy of some awesome information-space tool, the next day I'll look at a stupid infographic, read a story about universal-library vaporware, or see bit of design too clever for its own good and begin to doubt that better tools will make much of a difference. Either way I keep coming back to this desire to look in from outside at swirling systems of thought, to let the public inside a brain in action.

objects.name: New Works
objects.excerpt: New Works by Casey A. Gollan

objects.name: Mixing Metaphors: Skeuomorphic, Hyper, and...
objects.excerpt: There are some valid arguments for skeuomorphic design, for example mimicking the turning of real-life pages in a virtual book on the iPad, besides “wow, that looks cool!” One good one is that we’re in a transitional period where mimicry is being used to help people learn how to interact with these new touch devices, and that skeuomorphism will be replaced by less decorative interfaces in due time. There are also the criticisms: some vehemently oppose any computer interface with a torn paper edge and others are trying to invent less dated replacements for the “save” icon (which is still commonly represented by a floppy disk).

objects.name: Notes on Forgetting, Archiving, and Existing on...
objects.excerpt: What if instead of encouraging us to chatter, our tools helped us relate, merge, revise and evolve bits over time? What if we were to move away from the idea of the stream and towards editing and maintaining a non-linear constellation of ideas? What if instead of dealing with our glut of information by erasing it, we came up with ways to deprecate our past, update our present and make sure that our digital histories are preserved for the future? I think that somewhere between writing, remixing and reblogging, between editing a wiki and branching code on a project in Git, is a new model for existing online.

objects.name: SensitivePhotoGeneration.com
objects.excerpt: Drag and drop clichéd elements from “sensitive” photographs into new compositions.

objects.name: Attempted Conversation
objects.excerpt: I've tried and tried but I see no way to arrive at a sculpture. To go from the world of ideas and fragments of information to an object is a translation that I'm not convinced needs to happen. Do we need to critique the merits of an object? Can we have a conversation with no centerpiece? I've had richer experiences reading books than looking at art first-hand. I've thought of sculptures—100 shape-shifting sculptures a minutes—and then been done with them.

objects.name: Casey, Runner
objects.excerpt: Ran out of/with/away from class until I reached the Southern tip of Manhattan.

objects.name: Built to Last, Built to Decay: Authentic,...
objects.excerpt: Craig Mod, who clearly _gets it_, has written (and _designed_) [an excellent piece](http://craigmod.com/journal/ipad_and_books/) on the future of publishing:

objects.name: Gradient Bookshelf
objects.excerpt: I rearranged a few of my favorite books to form a gradient based on the color of the paper, then bent a metal shelf to perfectly contain them.

objects.name: Scattered Notes on the Blog as a Curated...
objects.excerpt: Blogs are a lame format for how we have come to use and peruse them. Someday I want to be the curator for an interesting blogger. Their job would be new acquisitions, which are vital, but the front page would be weekly rotating connections between archived content.

objects.name: I Don't Sketch Book
objects.excerpt: An experimental daily sketchbook that I designed for myself.

objects.name: Public Apology Project
objects.excerpt: We're all guilty of petty little crimes and it's time we own up. It’s the little things we do that ruin it for everyone else: clipping our nails in public, throwing our gum on the ground, or yelling at a waiter in a restaurant. By placing memorials to our mistakes in the places where we made them, we can publicly apologize for our actions and make sure that nobody repeats them. The public apology form serves to publicly embarrass the person who committed the misdemeanor, and also redeem them by helping others to not make the same mistake in the same place.
